titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the WSM Radio and Television Collection

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

repository.corpname: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

bioghist.head: Provenance
bioghist.p: President of National Life and Accident Insurance Company, the parent company of WSM, Inc., Jesse Wills appreciated the research value of the wide variety of material related to the activities of WSM Radio and TV. In May 1967 he donated to Vanderbilt University an assortment of this material and added to the collection in July 1968. Jesse Wills also donated the Grand Ole Opry Collection, which complements the WSM RADIO_& TV material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The WSM RADIO & TV collection is composed of correspondence, photographs, scripts of radio programs, and promotional material. It is stored in thirteen manuscript boxes, eight of which contain scripts of radio programs. Dates of the collection range from 1928 to 1966 with a large portion of the material dated in the 1940s.

WSM Radio is probably best known as the station that broadcasts the Grand Ole Opry. Scripts from Opry broadcasts together with autographs and photographs of Opry stars are among the collection's documents.

During World War II, Variety magazine sponsored a SHOWMANAGEMENT Award. In entries to the contest, WSM Radio outlined its contribution to the "war effort," using photographs to illustrate several points. The Federal Communications Commission Clear Channel Hearings of 1947 also serve as a good profile of WSM Radio during the 1940s.

chronitem.event: First radio broadcast over the National Life and Accident Insurance Company's radio station.
The "WSM Barn Dance," forerunner of the Grand Ole Opry is launched.
The "WSM Barn Dance" becomes the Grand Ole Opry.
WSM is awarded a clear channel at 650 kilocycles. Its power is increased from 5,000 watts to 50,000 watts.
The Grand Ole Opry is carried by the NBC Radio Network.
WSM becomes first American commercial frequency modulation radio station, W47NV, a forerunner of WSM-FM.
The Grand Ole Opry moves to the Ryman Auditorium and stays there for the next 31 years.
WSM-TV debuts as the first television station in Nashville, building its own microwave relay system to Louisville, KY
"The Waking Crew," the second longest running live radio broadcast, goes on the air under the name, "8 O'clock Time."
"Grand Ole Opry," WSM's first network show, is televised on ABC-TV.
WSM-TV becomes the first television station in the United States to receive satellite weather map photos transmitted from NASA's Nimbus satellite.
WSM-TV brings color programming to Nashville.
WSM-FM makes its debut with 100,000 watts.
Opryland U.S.A., an amusement park with a musical theme, has its official groundbreaking.
Opening of Opryland U.S.A.
The Grand Ole Opry moves into the Grand Ole Opry House situated on the grounds at Opryland.
Opryland Productions television and commercial production operation goes into business in the Grand Ole Opry House.
WSM-TV becomes the first Nashville television station to broadcast an hour-long local news program.
The Opryland Hotel, Tennessee's largest convention hotel property, opens.
The Grand Ole Opry is televsied live over the Public Broadcasting Service annually through 1981.
WSM forms Opry land Radio Productions to produce and market syndicated and network radio programming.
NLT Corporation, parent company of WSM, Inc., announces plans for the sale of WSM-TV to make way for WSM's entry into satellite and cable television programming.
"Nashville Alive," the first live cable television series to be telecast from Nashville, premieres from the Stagedoor Lounge of the Opryland Hotel, being telecast on WTBS from Atlanta.
WSM-TV is sold to Gillett Broadcasting Company and becomes WSMV-TV.
WSM and the Associated Press announce the Music Country Network, an overnight satellite radio network, with WSM-AM as the flagship station.
WSM announces a venture between Opry land Productions and Group W Satellite Communications for the Nashville Network satellite and cable operation.
